Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They are overseeing a crowded beach during high tide, where one moment of inattention could put multiple swimmers at serious risk.
Story: The sun blazed overhead as I scanned the crowded beach, my eyes darting from one bobbing head to another. Every muscle in my body was tense, alert for the slightest sign of trouble. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder for the weekly call to my stepdad. He always said these calls meant a lot, that they made him feel like I was really part of the family. I knew he’d be waiting, probably watching the clock, hoping I wouldn’t forget. But the waves were rough today, and the beach was packed. I couldn’t look away, not even for a minute. The expectation to be present for my family tugged at me, but so did the responsibility to keep these strangers safe. My heart pounded as I weighed the importance of a simple conversation against the possibility of missing a cry for help. I stared at the phone, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in, unsure which demand I could afford to ignore.
